required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Cognitive Outcomes After Perioperative Care
clinical_study.official_title: Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Cognitive Outcomes After Perioperative Care

brief_summary.textblock: This study will examine the hypothesis that changes in the cognition (i.e. thinking and memory) after anesthesia and surgery are correlated with changes in markers of Alzheimers Disease in the fluid around the brain and spinal cord (i.e. cerebrospinal fluid, or CSF), and/or changes in brain connectivity. The investigators will also examine whether different types of anesthesia have different effects on these CSF markers of Alzheimers disease, or different effects on thinking and memory after anesthesia and surgery, or differential effects on the correlation between cognitive changes and CSF marker changes.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation Between Perioperative Change in Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Perioperative Cognitive Change
primary_outcome.description: Spearman correlation was used here as the CSF markers follow a skewed distribution. Spearman correlation describes the strength of the monotonic relationship between two measures and is bounded between -1 and 1. Negative values indicate an inverse relationship while positive values mean that the variables move in tandem.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation Between Perioperative Change in Ratios of Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Perioperative Cognitive Change
primary_outcome.description: Spearman correlation was used here as the ratio of CSF markers follow a skewed distribution. Spearman correlation describes the strength of the monotonic relationship between two measures and is bounded between -1 and 1. Negative values indicate an inverse relationship while positive values mean that the variables move in tandem.

secondary_outcome.measure: Continuous Cognitive Index Score Change Difference Between Anesthetic Agent Groups
secondary_outcome.description: To characterize cognitive function over time, while minimizing potential redundancy in the cognitive measures, a factor analysis was performed on the 10 cognitive test scores from baseline. To quantify overall cognitive function, a baseline cognitive index was first calculated as the mean of the preoperative domain scores. The cognitive index score has a mean of zero, thus any positive score is above the mean, any negative score is below the mean. A continuous change score was then calculated by subtracting the baseline from the 6-week cognitive index. A negative change score indicating decline and a positive score indicating improvement. The resulting outcome measure is unbounded with a standard deviation of 0.31 in the full surgical cohort.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in CSF Markers of Alzheimers Disease by Anesthetic Agent Group
secondary_outcome.description: CSF Markers of Alzheimer's Disease over time in the subjects treated with propofol versus those treated with isoflurane.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Ratio of CSF Markers of Alzheimers Disease by Anesthetic Agent Group
secondary_outcome.description: Change in ratio of CSF Markers of Alzheimer's Disease over time in the subjects treated with propofol versus those treated with isoflurane.
The perioperative change in the CSF tau/Abeta ratio from the start of anesthesia/surgery to 24 hours later.

arm_group.description: Patients in this arm will receive general anesthesia with propofol as the primary amnestic agent.
Patients in this arm will undergo general anesthesia with isoflurane as the primary amnestic agent.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Surgical patients 60 years of age or older
- Surgery scheduled to last at least 2 hours (including time for anesthesia induction, etc)
- English speaking ability.
- Ability to give informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inmate of a correctional facility (i.e. prisoners).
- Pregnancy
- Documented or suspected family or personal history of malignant hyperthermia.
- Patient unable to receive either propofol or isoflurane due to allergy or other specific contraindication.

overall_official.affiliation: Duke University Medical Center, Anesthesiology Department, Neuroanesthesia Division

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: General Anesthesia With Isoflurane
group.description: Surgical patients randomized to receive inhalational anesthesia with isoflurane during surgery

group.title: Total Intravenous Anesthesia With Propofol
group.description: Surgical patients randomized to receive intravenous anesthesia with propofol during surgery

group.title: Non-Surgical Controls
group.description: Cohort of community dwelling healthy controls for tertiary comparison

participants_list.participants: This represents the number of enrolled patients who completed baseline cognitive testing

baseline.population: Subjects who returned for six-week follow-up visit.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Correlation Between Perioperative Change in Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Markers of Alzheimers Disease and Perioperative Cognitive Change
outcome.description: Spearman correlation was used here as the CSF markers follow a skewed distribution. Spearman correlation describes the strength of the monotonic relationship between two measures and is bounded between -1 and 1. Negative values indicate an inverse relationship while positive values mean that the variables move in tandem.
outcome.population: Analysis for the primary and secondary outcome 6 use the combination of both randomized treatment groups. The treatment groups are separated and compared in secondary analysis of outcomes 3-5, and the control group is only used in tertiary analyses. To be included in the outcome analysis patients must have returned for six-week follow-up visit.

group.title: Combined Surgical Cohort
group.description: The combination of both surgical randomized treatment groups.

outcome.description: To characterize cognitive function over time, while minimizing potential redundancy in the cognitive measures, a factor analysis was performed on the 10 cognitive test scores from baseline. The cognitive index score has a mean of zero, thus any positive score is above the mean, any negative score is below the mean. The resulting outcome measure is unbounded with a standard deviation of 0.31 in the full surgical cohort.

To be included in the outcome analysis patients must have returned for six-week follow-up visit.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
